Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 07:56PM sueopp wrote: Hi Karen - yup, I had to have my power port replaced, but all has been very well since.  The tip off was that they seemed to be unable to pull much of anything from my port (such as blood work and etc.) and it gradually got worse.  A very astute oncology nurse figured out what was wrong - it seems that one of the tube-like thingys splintered under my skin, and a little bit of stuff was leaking into the tissues around the port (Yikes!).  It was determined that the port itself was defective. They quickly got the bad booger out and put a new booger in and it has been easy going since (18 months so far).  Don't worry, I'm betting that things will be fine.  PS:  since mine "splintered" which I guess means many leaks, I have to watch for little splinters that the surgeon wasn't able to get, and which very occasionally make their way to the surface of my skin.  Crappy cancer!  Fondly,  SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: I was diagnosed stage IV at Christmas time. After a year had gone by and another Christmas was coming around, I became convinced that it would be my Last Christmas. After all, I had already used up more than one of my possible two year prognosis. Weepy and crumpled, I posted about it along with some others. Also at this time there was a woman posting on the boards named JillHut. She was smart as a whip, accomplished, fearless, with a wicked sense of humor. She replied (and I am paraphrasing): "Yeah, girls, I remember feeling that way. Just want to tell you that I am working on my fifth "Last Christmas", so take heart." She did need to leave us, but only after several more "Last Christmases". I want to tell you that now I am working on MY fifth "Last Christmas" and am looking forward to my sixth, my seventh, my eighth... Keeping JillHut in my heart. As the excellent exbmxgrl reminds us, Life does not end with a stage IV diagnosis (really!). Happy holidays everyone - SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2015 11:34AM sueopp wrote: SO...sitting on the parking lot at the mall and shaking - Apparently the cashiers at Penney's are trained to ask customers at checkout if they would like to round up to the next dollar for "breast cancer awareness". Standing in line I resolved not to say a word, but when she asked my resolve disappeared. I leaned in and started to whisper to her - the usual stuff we all know, much goes to research and science vs. awareness, how A CURE gets lost in the clutter, how companies are not actually required to turn anything over, and to whom, how we hate Puketober etc. etc. well this kid just looks at me and says. "You mean it might not go to curing breast cancer?" I felt like a real creep. Here is this nice young woman trying to do something nice for people - aughhhhh, I HATE HATE HATE this sh**. (Ok, I'm done now). Love to all SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: Hanging out at the ole outpatient radiology dept and drinking the crap pre-scans, I thought I might share about a lovely thing that happened this morning. I have no religious or faith commitment or identification.  The closest I can get is to see the power and force of good in every human being (god?).  Tanya is a Presbyterian minister and is the chaplain whose beat is the outpatient oncology center.  Every week when I am in the chair, Tanya comes to see me so we can commune together.  We talk about books (we both read nonstop), family (she has a wife, I have a husband), travel and so on.  At the end of the visit we hold hands and meditate for a moment or two.  I care about her and she helps me. As I was dragging my terrified heart to the scan dept, who should I see but the excellent Tanya coming down the hall.  She knew I was heading for scans (how?) and just wanted to tell me she thought all would be well, her nose told her so.  Talk about taking a risk - Sounds like such a stupid little thing when I put it into words, but my heart soared at the time. Somebody in this world feels like it's going to be OK.  Is this what they call a blessing?  Love to all, SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 05:17AM sueopp wrote: Hi Dawn16, I also am on the xeloda & tykerb regimen.  I am told that the tykerb is all about good absorbtion, and so I elected to take it at 3 PM each afternoon.  I know that I will be awake at that time of day (!) and I stop any food by 1 PM, then don't have nuthin' until after 5 PM.  This is probably overkill - I think the company says no food for 1 hour before and 1 hour after, but why not give it lots of time?  PS:  it sometimes causes me a bit of heartburn or sour stomach in the afternoon, and the oncology nurse told me to suck on a hard candy (not mint).  Best of luck - SUE

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 04:07PM sueopp wrote: Hello and best regards everyone.  I'm Sue, 63 years old, married to a lovely Englishman, mother of fully launched son and daughter, grandmother of 4.  Stage IV for a bit over 2 years, with mets to the lungs, fairly well contained.  They won't go away, but don't seem to travel either.  Am seriously HER2+++, so have done alot of herceptin together with some others (xeloda, tykerb, and a failed stint with TDM1).  I stay at home, and try to do as much volunteering as I can - my mom convinced me when I was young that reaching out to others was a good way to take your mind off your own troubles (sometimes works, sometimes not).  Moved recently from "the big house" into a smaller condo, so that recently retired husband and I can travel more and spend more time together.  Lots of changes in my world - HA!  The boards help to keep me steady, so thanks to each and everyone.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 08:01AM sueopp wrote: Just to be clear, folks - SSDI is automatic compassionate allowance in our state (Maryland) but only if you have worked in the last five years.  So if you have been a stay at home mom or have been retired etc. and not drawn a paycheck in 5 years, you will be disallowed.  I guess this makes sense in a way - if one hasn't worked out of the home in that time, one can't turn around and say "pay me now because I can't work outside of the home".  Although honestly, I think we deserve every compassionate allowance out there.  Best to all - SUE

Posts.Content: May 28, 2015 01:35PM sueopp wrote: Stef, your post made me pause and think. Like Ronnie (hi hon!) I decided early on to tell people - not strangers or distant folks, but all my close friends know, all my family members know (we are a close family), even my friends at soup kitchen where I work. For me, this has just made things more simple. On the other hand, I also definitely did not want to deal with "the look" from people who know (pity, fear, etc) nor did I want to fool with inappropriate or intrusive questions. I have to admit that my solution has been to "do my theater" - that is, I adapt a tone and demeanor when "it" comes up so that I get the kind of response I want. Pretty controlling I know. But the good news is that for the most part I feel pretty good and have been pretty lucky, so that's what gets communicated. When I need some TLC, I know who I can lean on. I'm sorry that your situation has changed, Stef, but there is good news to be had on these boards and love and support as well. SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: Here's one for our collective think tank: I spend a hunk of my summer days visiting in Chincoteague, Virginia, where the folklore has it that the mosquitoes are as big as the Chincoteague ponies. Actually not quite, but they really are huge and so aggressive. And wherever I am, those boogers make a B-line for my port. They are like vampires, and I know they can smell me coming. Since I had port infections twice over the last two summers, once requiring hospitalization, and each time right after returning from Chincoteague, it is my theory that these vampire bugs infect me with other people's germs, since they imbibe over and over from host to host (ewwwwww!). Today I returned from the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and there they are: four huge mosquito bites all too close to my port. And this time I kept it covered with gauze and tape. I sprayed (sorta, certainly not too near the port) but used a spray that didn't have the poisonous DEET ingredient. So I'm trying to figure out how to ward off these monsters. Just go ahead and saturate myself with poison? Skin-So-Soft? (Remember that?) Turtlenecks? Waddya think, girls? Grateful for anyinteresting ideas. SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2014 09:20AM sueopp wrote: I have been on a combo of herceptin, perjeta and navelbine for over a year now.  Navelbine certainly has some SEs, but with some help it can be very doable.  Re: the bloating & stomach pain , very common with navelbine.  My doc put me on a proton pump inhibitor (usually given for acid reflux ) and the symptoms went away-yea!  Also my doc lowered my navelbine dose by half to reduce other symptoms, and it still seems to be working.   Seems to me you need to find a doctor who will work better with you and your mom - I know that's scary, but she should not be suffering as she is.  Good luck - SUE

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2014 05:46AM sueopp wrote: VL,  both herceptin and perjeta are drugs that are specifically designated to work for women whose breast cancer is HER2 positive.  I think that they fall into the category of "targeted therapy", that is, they attack the cancer cells without damaging the normal cells.  Testing to see if a tumor is HER2+ is routinely done when the tumor is biopsied.  Your mom's doc should be able to tell you how she tested. And if she hasn't been tested for this, she will want to be - more good drugs in the arsenal.  Good luck - SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: Folks - I don't always post about my ups and downs, but am having a problem, and who has better ideas than the people on this site? In brief, since mid June I have been on a combo of herceptin/perjeta/navelbine.  I have had sometimes terrible/sometimes managable/ongoing/all over the place and finally escalating abdominal & stomach pain, which culminated in a very long visit to the ER a couple of days ago.  After testing for everything in the book, we learned a) that my lung mets are reduced by 1/3 to 1/2 (!!!) b) that the whole rest of my body, including abdomen, colon, liver and etc are completely clean (again, !!!) c) that I don't have C-diff or any other kind of infection So what is causing this awful pain?  The prevailing theory is that I am having a very rare pain reaction to the navelbine.  Nobody seems to have heard of this happening before, but it is an unlikely but documented SE.  The only temporary solution has been acupuncture (works for a day or two) and for me to take oxycodone throughout the day, which I am doing.  The question:  We have a pow-wow set up with trusted oncologist for Friday to explore strategies.  Oncologist's first suggestion is to reduce the chemo (please, nooooooooo).  We also have thought about a GI consult, a visit to a pain management clinic, medical marijuana.  Anybody else have a good idea?  I am so happy about the scans, but this SE is unrelenting.  PS:  my bone mets sisters - I have a new understanding of the daily pain that you suffer.  I humbly salute you and send my love.    Thanks folks - SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2015 10:55AM sueopp wrote: Dear Patti, I know that you must be feeling so nervous and upset just now, but there is lots of good news for you. I too am HER2+ and have been from the start. Over the last several years HER2+ breast cancers have received huge amounts of attention and research time and money. Consequently there are great drugs which have been developed especially for us and that work very well. You will likely receive herceptin and might also be given perjeta. Both of these are "targeted therapies " which basically means that they attack the cancer cells and for the most part leave your healthy cells alone, meaning minimal side effects (!). There will be a lot for you to learn about your new status, but take a breath - HER2 + doesn't mean what it used to. Good luck - SUE

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2015 02:54AM sueopp wrote: Hi Macy, hope it's ok for me to chime in here, and sorry that you are feeling so low. I/we understand and are with you all the way. Just wanted to comment about the herceptin fail you described. Most of we Hersies have been on herceptin for long periods of time, thru progressions and past them. I am no doctor, but my understanding is that combos that include herceptin are greater than the sum of their parts. For instance: when herceptin is given with taxol and perjeta, the three boost each other's effectiveness (1+1+1 = 5). I'm sure that your doctor can describe this better than I, but you might want to ask him/her. Good luck Macy - better living thru science. SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: This post might make me sound like the crackpot of the year, but I think I have stumbled on a fix for those wretched nighttime leg cramps that plague some of us.  Since starting herceptin/perjeta/navelbine over a year ago, I have been awakened repeatedly, sometimes several times a night, by "charley horse" type cramps in the legs.  These require me to get out of bed and stand up, trying to stretch the knot out before trying to fall asleep again.  Frustrating, irritating, painful. They became particularly bad last month, and in desperation I tried a solution that I read about in a newspaper column in our local called "The People's Pharmacy".  Folks had written in over the years to claim that putting a bar of soap in their bed stopped leg cramps -HUH?  I assumed that if by chance this weird solution did work, it was for people with restless leg syndrome or etc.  However I put a bar of Dove soap under the bottom sheet of our bed between the mattress and the sheet,  and ladies I kid you not:  I have not had a single cramp in my legs since.  I have waited for two weeks to see if anything changes, but nope, my leg thing seems to be fixed. Why would this work?  I dunno, but Oh! What a relief it is -  Love to all,  SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 06:16AM sueopp wrote: Hi LuAnn, me too!  And obviously so many others of us struggle with the sleep problem, including even the women who don't have cancer - a curse!  I don't want to take alot of drugs, mostly because I try to save the big guns for when I might need them.  On the other hand, a really good night's sleep once in a while can work miracles for a person, both physically and emotionally.  My solution is to take .5 mg of lorazepam (I think that's valium) one night out of every 5.  Gives me a solid 8-9 hours, no "hangover" in the morning, and then a 1 or 2 more decent sleeps before the insomnia is back.  Whatever works - best of luck.  SUE

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 05:16PM sueopp wrote: Hi Marsha, I am no longer on xeloda but continue to take tykerb together with herceptin.  I tried taking it in the middle of the afternoon, as I thought my stomach would be most empty then - big mistake!  The fine ladies on this board convinced me that right before bedtime is a good time (make sure stomach is empty - no food for 1-2 hours prior), and some women actually lay it out before bed and take it in the middle of the night, then go back to sleep.  Unfortunately even with this time change I still have to run to the bathroom sometimes.  The nurses told me to take immodium immediately after an "incident" - don't wait or put it off.  They also recommended that I take the full amout recommended - it won't hurt.  Also I was never a yogurt eater, but have added greek yogurt daily, and I am thinking that this is helping too.  Finally, say goodbye to anything raw, green and leafy, especially lettuce and salads, and red wine seems to bring it on as well.  Good luck hon.  SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: Husband, friends and I went to the eastern shore of Maryland on Friday to celebrate the holiday.  This trip required crossing the Bay Bridge (5 miles long) and took about 45 minutes in heavy, slow moving traffic.  I was repeatedly glancing at the white car in front of me as we crept along, and I noticed it's license plate which showed a pink ribbon and the words CURE 4.  Suddenly it dawned on me:  It couldn't be anything else - she's one of us!  I was so very excited - another woman, like us, who has found a great way to tell the world that we need a cure Now, dammit!  I couldn't find a way to get her attention, but I wanted to throw her a kiss. It also gave me a chance to talk to our friends about the stunning lack of research funds and attention for stage IV disease.  So if you are out there CURE 4, I want you to know that you made my day.  Thank you my sister - SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: Well, it's my turn for the scan anxiety - coming up fast, and am having trouble controlling the hysteria and nervousness that I feel, so wanted to touch base with "my base".  This scan is the first since I started the xeloda/tykerb regimen 6 months ago.  I have already had the CT scan (insurance company wouldn't authorize a PET - guess they thought they knew better than my beloved oncologist).  The timing was, as always, inconvenient.  My AirForce soldier boy and wife and son have returned to the US this week after a four year post in Germany and are staying with us for a week before reporting to NJ.  I decided to have the scan the day before they arrived and will go for the results the day after they leave-on Wednesday.  I keep trying to not "borrow trouble" but with this wretched disease, it's so hard, as you all know.  I don't feel any different at all from my initial diagnosis with mets (lots to the lungs) - no weird new stuff, but I know that this means nothing.  I look fine and feel pretty good (except for SE) and mets could still be exploding in me.  Even my bloods are perfect; in 11 years I have not had a single cancer marker show up.  Even so I know I am Stage IV and am incurable, and that I could start the downhill at any time.  I am afraid.  I know so many of you have been there, and when I am going crazy I read about the amazing successes and the amazing courage you all write about.  It helps so much.  Thanks for listening and wish me good karma on Wednesday.  SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2016 02:30AM sueopp wrote: Dear ajohnson, sorry you are having such a hard time. I did this combo for about two years and the results were great - stable, stable, stable. The diarrhea was tough for sure. The nurses told me to take as much Imodium as I needed, more than the label said, and I lived on the stuff. That and figuring out which foods were worse and which were better (no coffee, red wine, fried food, fats etc. for example) and I was ok eventually. I know that there are prescription drugs that can help. A word of caution: xeloda can cause some serious foot problems, and the sooner you jump on any hint of a problem the better. There are some xeloda threads somewhere on these boards with lots of good advice. Good luck and hang tough. SUE

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 11:54PM sueopp wrote: keepon:  I am sorry that you had to put up with those insensitive clods.  Early in my BC days when I was bald as a baby (the first time) I wore hats and scarves rather than a wig.  On one occasion, a woman came up to me, gave me a great big smile and said "That's a really cute hat!"  Before I could stop myself I said "Yup, but there's no hair under it" and then she said "Yeah, I've done that - twice".  Another big smile, we talked a little bit more and connected.  Thru the years and only when it seemed right, I have smiled at women and said "That's a real cute hat" or "I just love those earrings!".  Many have smiled back and we have talked - some have just said "thank you" and moved on.  Message received.  I've thought about that first smart woman and how she found a way to be caring without being rude, intrusive or hurtful.    SUE

Posts.Content: sueopp wrote: This story starts with my getting the worst sinus infection in the world a month ago.  At the same time, I began to experience flashes (like the sun hitting a mirror) in the corner of my left eye, mostly in low light but regular.  My only thought was: well, here they are - brain mets.  Hysteria set in.  I finally got it together to see the primary care doctor who assured me that this was due to the sinus infection and she would take care of it.  Two Z-Pacs later, I was still flashing, and increasing.  Screwed up my nerve and mentioned it to the oncologist who was in a bad mood that day.  He wasn't particularly interested, just said "we will watch it".  Meanwhile I continued to flash away, and then heavy floaters appeared, and I got crazier still.  After confessing my terror to a smart girlfriend, she told me to go to the eye doctor, that she had learned that such things could be due simply to aging (who, me?). Ophthalmologist told me to get into his office pronto - worried about a retinal tear.  After four hours there, the greatest little Doogie Houser of a doctor told me the following:  "Brain mets?  Off the table.  Retinal tear?  Off the table.  Sinus infection?  No connection.  However, you do have a little bit of age on you, hon".  Yup, my girlfriend nailed it - flashers like mine are caused by the vitreous fluid of the eye thinning and pulling just a bit on the eye.  No fix, just gotta live with it.  So after torturing myself and everyone around me for 3 weeks, after being completely insane for 3 weeks,  the answer is:  I'm old.   I really, really wish I knew how to not be a crazy person when this kind of thing happens.  I hate cancer.  SUE Dx 12/2010, IDC, Stage IV, 26/35 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How to not be a crazy person? sueopp intothewoods

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 02:14PM sueopp wrote: Dear TexasRose, your story really moved me.  I am sorry for the heartbreak about your two younger sisters.  But - I am so amazed at your ability to keep yourself happy, strong and clear despite your having to fight BC.  I admire you.  Regarding your older sister, the one you need to manage your illness for, my view is that there are people in our lives for whom we have to do the work of managing our troubles for their sakes.  I'll bet that your sister fills other important spots in your life, and you clearly love her for this.  If she needs you to manage some of the scary part for her, and you feel that you can do it for her, that sounds like real love to me.  Nothing practical to offer, only sending my support to you.   SUE
